module.name: schedule

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of a data model that identifies activities, dependencies, durations and milestones associated with products described in a work breakdown structure. This includes the information necessary to produce Workflow Diagrams, Network Schedules, Gantt Charts and Resource Leveling.

module.usage_guide:
Within organizations and between organizations it is beneficial to be able to exchange plans and schedules. These may be at a high level where they deal with the tasks of work breakdown structure or at low and detailed level where they coordinate individual workers. This module captures information concerning schedules, resource allocation and leveling. This information is needed to manage the life cycle process of developing and using a system such that persons and organizations can coordinate their activities.
This module is constructed from several ISO/TS Application modules. The USE FROM connectivity associated with these modules are shown below in Figure 1 the Schedule concept map.
Schedule Concept Map
The modules shown within this figure that are primary contributors to AP233's schedule information modelling capability are:
The module
provides the capability to associate additional information with an activity method.
The module
provides the association of a value, represented by a class, to an attribute of an entity.
The module identifies the evaluation of conditions that impact an activity or its execution. The module records the parameter values evaluated and the logicalresult of the evaluation.
The module
captures the specification of a property of an activity, the representation of a property of an activity, or the use of an independent property in the definition of an activity.
The module
provides for the assignment of a property to product data, use of an independent property in the definition of an item and the association of a representation with a property.
The module
captures the recording of resources used or consumed by activities. It captures the usage or consumption of actual resources and types of resource items. It captures the relationship between the resource actually applied and realized with the corresponding resource requirement statements. It captures the relationship between the resource as realized and the corresponding resource events.
The module
captures the definition of a property that may be associated with a resource or related element. It captures the representation of a property that may be associated with a resource or related element; the use of an independent property in the definition of a resource, and the means to assign a property to a resource or related element. The entity property includes time intervals.
The module captures the identification of schemes that support the ordering of activities. It captures the identification of entries in a scheme, and the association of dates and times with schemes and entries in schemes. It captures the definition of relationships between entries within a scheme, including dependencies and sequencing. It captures the definition of relationships between schemes, and the definition of relationships between scheme entries and schemes that expand on entries.
The module captures the specification of a task as a sequence of instructions encoded as text. It captures the specification of a task as a structured set of instructions. It captures the association of pre-conditions to a task or a stage within a task, the association of post-conditions to a task or a stage within a task, and the assignment of a task.
The module captures the association of a time interval with product or activity data.
The module captures the definition and quantification of planned and recorded output, the relationship between work outputs, and the relationships between the work output and detailed descriptions of the output.

Extensible type select lists (generic)
The problem of creating extensible type lists has proven to be an extreme challenge. A publish and subscribe analogy is used to explain the approach used.
Schemas enable information modelling capability within a domain. The capabilities are enabled by entities. Entities use other entities directly as specified attributes or less directly via extensible select types. The associated extensible select type list can be viewed as a subscription list. The list itself contains all entity names associated with entitiy concepts that subscribe to the capability offered by the schema containing the entity that uses the extensible type list as an attribute.
The complexity of the extensible select type list specification problem stems from the fact that lists are relative to a sub-domain of the domain associated with the schema that defines the extensible type list.
This creates a list creation problem that is 3 dimensional. The coordinate axes are:
domain specified by all USE FROM schemas,
extensible select types defined within this domain,
entities defined within a sub-domain of this domain.
To size this, AP233 has about 10 major domains, 1000 entities and 100 extensible types. If one does not apply some organizational logic to the problem this implies a yes/no cognitive decisions space containing 1,000,000 points.
In order to penetrate this problem some logical approach that is both scalable and checkable is required. In AP233 WD1 all schemas where grouped into high level concept groups: program managment resource infomration (pmri), organization structure (os), project breakdown (pb). schedule (ss) and work structure (ws). As AP233 WD2 evolved major module restructuring occured and the ability to group at a more detail level of abstraction was enabled.
